awd_titl_txt: Diatom-Enabled Scalable Nanomanufacturing for Photonic Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
As a major group of microalgae, diatoms have long been the inspiration and source material in many research fields. The intricate morphology of the abundant nanostructured silicon dioxide exoskeletons (also known as frustules) have led to numerous studies. To date, diatom frustules have been used in fluorescence immunoassays because their nanopores provide large surface areas for the bonding of bio-molecules. They have also been used as anode materials in dye sensitized solar cells because of their excellent light scattering property. The numerous nanostructures on diatom frustules are markedly uniform, however, they are seldom used in the scalable manufacturing of nanopatterns. This award advances the knowledge of how to utilize diatom frustule nanostructures on a large scale, by developing a better understanding of the interaction between diatom frustules and their surrounding gas/liquid/solid environments. This understanding is harnessed to produce large-area, uniform diatom frustule assemblies, followed by the replication of their nanostructures in two- and three-dimensions. Specifically, the photonic properties of these assemblies and their replicas are investigated and tailored towards specific photonic applications. The project provides a series of outreach modules tailored towards educating young researchers, including women and underrepresented minorities, and for fostering their passion in nanoscience and nanomanufacturing technologies.

Diatoms are unicellular photosynthetic microalgae which are ubiquitous in aquatic environments and remarkably diverse, with the estimated number of living species on the order of tens of thousands. As a potentially low-cost biomaterial, diatom frustules contain dense arrays of highly uniform nanopores, the diameters of which are as small as 40-60 nm. To fully utilize these remarkable nanostructures, diatom-enabled scalable nanomanufacturing approaches are explored in this work. Typical diatom frustule morphologies (e.g. Coscinodiscus sp. and Pinnularia sp.) are used to investigate different strategies in developing large-area frustule monolayers. This project addresses the fundamental and technological issues of the interactions between frustule and liquid-air and liquid-solid interfaces, and harnessing these interactions to achieve uniformly oriented compact frustule monolayers for subsequent nanopatterning. By analyzing computational and experimental results of such interactions, this research seeks to optimize diatom monolayer assembly formation through optimizing the frustule surface treatment and fluid flow conditions. Following the frustule assemblies, nanopattern transfer techniques are studied towards the 2D and 3D replication of frustule nanostructures through surface micromachining and micro-molding techniques. In addition, the light scattering properties of the frustule assemblies and their replicas are investigated. The replicated nanopatterns mirroring the hierarchical nanopores of the frustules are specifically tailored towards photonic applications, such as IR absorbers and photonic crystal filters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop cost-effective, controllable, and scalable diatom interaction-based manipulation techniques at the micro/nano scale, which are envisioned to provide wide-ranging benefits both in the study of frustule properties and in various practical photonic applications, such as the manufacture of photonic and sensing technologies, novel drug delivery platforms, energy applications, and more. Diatoms are incredibly diverse photosynthetic microalgae, widely distributed in aquatic environments. The wide array and intricate morphology of their micro- and nanostructured silica exoskeletons (frustules) present a tremendous opportunity for the development of biologically enabled advanced manufacturing technologies.

Diatoms have been previously used to enhance optical performance in applications such as sensing and solar cells. However, much of the research has focused on individual diatoms or bulk frustules. To fully leverage diatom frustules for scalable nanomanufacturing, it is essential to manipulate their unique pore distribution and geometries effectively. Scalable methods for this manipulation are limited, and this project seeks to address this gap by exploring several areas. One area of focus is the formation and manipulation of diatom frustules, where the effects of environmental conditions on their size, shape, and orientation are examined. The goal is to establish methods for assembling and integrating frustules into nanofabrication processes. Furthermore, the project delves into hierarchical porous structures within the frustules, thoroughly analyzing the biomorphic micro-/nano-patterns across various layers. By incorporating deep learning, the project aims to design diatom-inspired metamaterials and photonic devices based on these complex structures.

The use of bio-templates to synthesize inorganic nano/microstructures has been a significant source of inspiration for designing and fabricating intricate, high-surface-area materials with strong applications in nanotechnology. This approach remains a cost-effective alternative for synthesizing size- and shape-controlled patterned nanostructures compared to various other nanofabrication techniques. While studies on uniformly shaped particles, such as spheres, interacting with air-liquid interfaces are well-developed, the behavior of non-uniform particles like diatom frustules remains relatively unexplored. This project focuses on understanding these interactions and facilitating the large-scale assembly of diatom frustules. Additionally, fabrication techniques to replicate diatom morphology are being developed, allowing for scalable biologically mediated nanomanufacturing processes.

Diatom frustules feature hierarchical porous structures arranged in a hexagonal pattern, with pore sizes ranging from micrometer-scale foramen pores to nanometer-scale cribellum pores. This unique multilayered architecture has attracted significant interest across various interdisciplinary research fields, serving as a source of biomorphic inspiration. In practical validation of the diatom-based nanomanufacturing approach, this project explores the development of electromagnetic metamaterial absorbers in the infrared (IR) regime and subwavelength color-printing metamaterials in the visible (VIS) regime. The optical properties of large-area diatom arrays and their replicas are meticulously analyzed, focusing on light manipulation influenced by diatom orientation and fabrication techniques. The replication of diatom nanopores is utilized to create photonic absorbers spanning the VIS to IR spectrum for practical applications.

Efforts have been made in several areas, including the formation and manipulation of diatom frustules, which enables large-scale, controlled assembly. This aspect investigates the interaction properties between frustules, liquids, and other materials, employing self-assembly and microfluidic techniques to produce single-layer, close-packed, uniformly oriented diatom arrays. Additionally, techniques such as stencil and imprint lithography are utilized for diatom-templated nanopattern transfer and synthesis, along with the development of the vapor-liquid-solid (VLS) method to incorporate silica nanowires on the surface of C. sp. diatom frustules to enhance light scattering.

The project also examines diatom-inspired metamaterials and their photonic applications by analyzing the reflectance, absorptance, and transmittance of diatom patterns through experimental and simulation methods. This work has led to the fabrication of diatom-inspired metamaterial absorbers in both the IR and visible regimes. Furthermore, a deep learning-assisted approach is applied to the design of diatom-inspired metasurfaces, optimizing the design-to-learn-to-design (D2L2D) algorithm to facilitate the creation of these dielectric structures.

Overall, the goal of this project is to utilize innovative engineering methods to best benefit from diatom frustules for the nanofabrication purposes, for the scalable fabrication of photonic devices including but not limited to metasurface devices and diatom-templated advanced photonic materials. The interdisciplinary nature of this research—spanning biology, chemistry, materials science, micro/nano systems, and artificial intelligence—has fostered collaboration across multiple fields. The project has offered graduate students valuable opportunities to engage in both basic and applied research, mentor junior members, and publish in high-impact journals. Along the way, multiple honors and awards have been received. Additionally, undergraduate students have actively contributed, gaining hands-on experience and inspiration through their involvement in the design, fabrication, and testing of micro- and nanoparticles.
